|The [http://eotarchive.cdlib.org End of Term Web Archive] captures and saves U.S. Government federal government websites ([[.gov]], .mil, etc) in the Legislative, Executive, or Judicial branches of the government at the end of presidential administrations. Beginning in 2008, the EOT has thus far preserved websites from administration changes in 2008, 2012 and 2016, and is currently gearing up for the 2020 transition. [http://eotarchive.cdlib.org/partners.html Project partners] include [[California Digital Library|CA Digital Library]], Internet Archive, Library of Congress, George Washington University, Stanford University, University of North Texas, and the US Government Publishing Office.
|-
| [[Pandora Archive|Australia's Web Archive]]<ref name="Australia's Web Archive">{{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/ |title=Pandora — Australia's Web Archive |publisher=nla.gov.au |date= May 1999|access-date=2013-11-17}}</ref>
| Australia
| 1996
| [[Pandora Archive|PANDORA Digital Archiving System (PANDAS)]], Heritrix, Bamboo, [[Trove|NLA Trove]], [[HTTrack]], Webrecorder, outbackCDX.
| 4
| >10
| The [[National Library of Australia]] leads the 'PANDORA' component of the Australian Web Archive which takes a selective approach and is a collaborative program of 10 agencies providing curatorial input. PANDORA uses the PANDAS workflow system (developed by the NLA in the late 1990s) with HTTrack as the default harvester. The [[National Library of Australia]] also conducts bulk harvesting of Australian government (the Australian Government Web Archive) websites using the Heritrix harvester and Webrecorder with a backend infrastructure (referred to as 'Bamboo') to organise content and the NLA developed outbackCDX tool to manage indexing access restrictions for content. In addition to these approaches the National Library also conducts annual harvests of the whole .au domain which is donein collaboration with the [[Internet Archive]] using [[Heritrix]] [[Wayback Machine|and Wayback]]. In 2019, PANDORA, the Australian Government Web Archive and the whole domain harvests were integrated into a new single discovery and delivery portal through the NLA's Trove discovery service.
|-

Acquisition policy consists of three lines: selective harvests (collection of resources based on selection criteria), topic collections (focused on significant topics in the area of the Czech web) and comprehensive harvests (automatic harvests of content on the national domain). Staff contains 1 manager, 3.5 curators + 1.5 technical staff. |}

|The [https://archive-it.org/collections/12090 EU Web Archive] compiles the captures of the websites of the [https://european-union.europa.eu/institutions-law-budget/institutions-and-bodies_en European Union institutions], which are hosted on the europa.eu domain and subdomains. Its aim is to preserve EU web content in the long term and to keep it accessible for the public. The archive was created in 2013 by the [https://www.eui.eu/en/academic-units/historical-archives-of-the-european-union Historical Archives of the European Union] and in 2018, the [[Publications Office of the European Union#Collections and Services|Publications Office of the EU]] took over this task and created the EU Web Archive service. The collection of archived websites is covered by the [https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/3970ecec-e222-11ec-a534-01aa75ed71a1 EU Legal Deposit scheme], which collects all the material produced by EU entities in a comprehensive bibliography.

| PROMISE project<ref name="PROMISE project">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/projects/promise-project/ |title=PROMISE project |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref>
| Belgium
| 2017
| [[Heritrix]], PyWB
| 
| 7
| The PROMISE project was a two-year project (2017–2019) that explored the policy-related, legal, technical and scientific issues related to archiving the Belgian web. The aim of the project was to a) identify best practices in the field of web-archiving b) develop a strategy for preserving the Belgian web c) set up a pilot for preserving and providing access to the archived Belgian web and d) make recommendations for the implementation of a sustainable web-archiving service. The project was launched by the Royal Library of Belgium<ref name="Royal Library of Belgium">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/ |title=Royal Library of Belgium |publisher=www.kbr.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> and the State Archives of Belgium<ref name="State Archives of Belgium">{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.be/index.php?l=en |title=State Archives of Belgium |publisher=www.arch.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> in collaboration with Ghent University (Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication<ref name="Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication">{{cite web|url=https://www.ugent.be/ps/communicatiewetenschappen/mict/en |title=Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication Technologies |publisher=www.ugent.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> and Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities),<ref name="Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities">{{cite web|title=Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities|url=http://www.ghentcdh.ugent.be/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=www.ghentcdh.ugent.be}}</ref> Université de Namur (Research Centre in Information, Law and Society)<ref name="Research Centre in Information, Law and Society">{{cite web|title=Research Centre in Information, Law and Society|url=http://www.crids.eu/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=www.crids.eu/}}</ref> and Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant<ref name="Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant">{{cite web|url=http://he2b.be/|title=Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant |publisher=he2b.be/ |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> (Unité de Recherche et de Formation en Sciences de l'Information et de la Documentation). In October 2019 the concluding colloquium 'Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive')<ref name="Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive">{{cite web|title=Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/agenda/saving-the-web-the-promise-of-a-belgian-web-archive/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=KBR}}</ref> took place at KBR. The main research findings were presented during this colloquium. 
|-
| KBR web archive<ref name="KBR web archive">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/ |title=KBR web archive |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref>
| Belgium
| 2020
| 
| 1
| 
| KBR<ref name="KBR">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/|title=KBR |publisher=www.kbr.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> or the [[Royal Library of Belgium|Belgian Royal Library]] is developing an operational web archive based on the findings of the PROMISE research project<ref name="PROMISE project">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/projects/promise-project/ |title=PROMISE project |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> (2017–2019). Operational policies and technical infrastructure will be developed based on the strategy outlined in the PROMISE project. |}

|The [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|UK National Archives]]'  EU Exit Web Archive is a fully open web archive. |The [https://archive-it.org/collections/12090 EU Web Archive] compiles the captures of the websites of the [https://european-union.europa.eu/institutions-law-budget/institutions-and-bodies_en European Union institutions], which are hosted on the europa.eu domain and subdomains. Its aim is to preserve EU web content in the long term and to keep it accessible for the public. The archive was created in 2013 by the [https://www.eui.eu/en/academic-units/historical-archives-of-the-european-union Historical Archives of the European Union] and in 2018, the [[Publications Office of the European Union#Collections and Services|Publications Office of the EU]] took over this task and created the EU Web Archive service. The collection of archived websites is covered by the [https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/3970ecec-e222-11ec-a534-01aa75ed71a1 EU Legal Deposit scheme], which collects all the material produced by EU entities in a comprehensive bibliography.

| PROMISE project<ref name="PROMISE project">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/projects/promise-project/ |title=PROMISE project |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref>
| Belgium
| 2017
| [[Heritrix]], PyWB

| 7
| The PROMISE project was a two-year project (2017–2019) that explored the policy-related, legal, technical and scientific issues related to archiving the Belgian web. The aim of the project was to a) identify best practices in the field of web-archiving b) develop a strategy for preserving the Belgian web c) set up a pilot for preserving and providing access to the archived Belgian web and d) make recommendations for the implementation of a sustainable web-archiving service. The project was launched by the Royal Library of Belgium<ref name="Royal Library of Belgium">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/ |title=Royal Library of Belgium |publisher=www.kbr.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> and the State Archives of Belgium<ref name="State Archives of Belgium">{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.be/index.php?l=en |title=State Archives of Belgium |publisher=www.arch.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> in collaboration with Ghent University (Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication<ref name="Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication">{{cite web|url=https://www.ugent.be/ps/communicatiewetenschappen/mict/en |title=Research Group for Media, Innovation and Communication Technologies |publisher=www.ugent.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> and Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities),<ref name="Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities">{{cite web|title=Ghent Centre for Digital Humanities|url=http://www.ghentcdh.ugent.be/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=www.ghentcdh.ugent.be}}</ref> Université de Namur (Research Centre in Information, Law and Society)<ref name="Research Centre in Information, Law and Society">{{cite web|title=Research Centre in Information, Law and Society|url=http://www.crids.eu/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=www.crids.eu/}}</ref> and Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant<ref name="Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant">{{cite web|url=http://he2b.be/|title=Haute-École Bruxelles-Brabant |publisher=he2b.be/ |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> (Unité de Recherche et de Formation en Sciences de l'Information et de la Documentation). In October 2019 the concluding colloquium 'Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive')<ref name="Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive">{{cite web|title=Saving the web: the promise of a Belgian web archive|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/agenda/saving-the-web-the-promise-of-a-belgian-web-archive/|access-date=2020-01-31|publisher=KBR}}</ref> took place at KBR. The main research findings were presented during this colloquium. 
|-
| KBR web archive<ref name="KBR web archive">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/ |title=KBR web archive |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref>
| Belgium
| 2020
| 
| 1
| 
| KBR<ref name="KBR">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/|title=KBR |publisher=www.kbr.be |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> or the [[Royal Library of Belgium|Belgian Royal Library]] is developing an operational web archive based on the findings of the PROMISE research project<ref name="PROMISE project">{{cite web|url=https://www.kbr.be/en/projects/promise-project/ |title=PROMISE project |access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref> (2017–2019). Operational policies and technical infrastructure will be developed based on the strategy outlined in the PROMISE project. |}

|The [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|UK National Archives]]'  EU Exit Web Archive is a fully open web archive. It contains a wide selection of documents taken from EUR-Lex (the European legislation website), including Treaties, legislative documents, the Official Journal of the EU, case law and other supporting materials, and judgements of the European Court of Justice in English, French and German. The collection contains all content published up to the completion of the implementation period, at 11pm GMT on 31 December 2020.<ref name="Exit Web Archive">{{cite web |title=EU Exit Web Archive - The National Archives |url=https://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/eu-exit/ |website=webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk |access-date=20 February 2021}} [[File:UKOpenGovernmentLicence.svg|30px]] Text was copied from this source, which is available under an [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/3/  Open Government Licence v3.0]. © Crown copyright.</ref>
